questions.text: With respect to the usage of needles in surgeries, Match the following needles with their correct usage: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-c , 2-a , 3-e , 4-b

Highyeild:

Types of Needle & their Usages: Round-bodied needles : Designed to separate tissue fibers rather than cut through them and are commonly used in intestinal and cardiovascular surgery. Cutting needles : Used where tough or dense tissue needs to be sutured, such as skin and fascia . Blunt-ended needles : Closure of the abdominal wall , to diminish the risk of needle-stick injuries in this era of virally transmitted disorders . Hand-held straight needles : Used on the skin , although today it is advocated that needle holders should be used in all cases to reduce the risk of needle-stick injuries. Half-circle needles : Commonly utilized in the gastrointestinal tract J-shaped needles, quarter-circle needles, and compound curvature needles : Utilized in laparoscopic port site closure, eye, and oral cavity, respectively

Extraedge:

Abdominal Wall Closure : Recent studies have shown decreased incisional hernia when the interval between sutures is reduced to 0.5 cm and performed using a smaller-sized needle (2.0 PDS as opposed to the much larger 1 PDS) . It is argued that the larger needle causes BUTTONHOLE DEFECTS when compared with the entry point of a narrow needle and thread

questions.text: The advantages of Bipolar Diathermy over Monopolar Diathermy are all Except:

options.label: B
options.text: Must not be used in Circumcision and surgeries near the nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Can be safely used in pacemakers

options.label: D
options.text: Current is between the limbs of the diathermy probe

questions.correct_answer: B. Must not be used in Circumcision and surgeries near the nerve
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Must not be used in Circumcision and surgeries near the nerve

Highyeild:

In Monopolar surgery , the electrical current created in the ESU passes through a single electrode (diathermy pencil) to the tissue, causing the desired tissue effect (cut or coagulation). Electrical energy is passed via the diathermy probe and returned to the machine via the patient earth plate. Earth plate must be far away from the pacemaker. It must not be used in circumcision and surgeries near the nerve. In Bipolar diathermy , the two active electrodes are usually represented by the limbs of a pair of diathermy forceps, blades of scissors, or graspers. It needs no Earth Plate. The current is between the limbs of the diathermy probe. Can be safely used in pacemakers. Safe in surgeries near nerve and Circumcision . Effects of Diathermy : Coagulation: to achieve haemostasis; Cutting: incision and dissection of tissues during surgery Hazards of Diathermy : Burns Electrocution Explosion Channeling Interference with implantable electronic devices Occupational hazards from surgical smoke Laparoscopic surgery and diathermy injuries

questions.text: All are causes of Primary lymphedema except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary malignancy

Highyeild:

Lymphoedema : Lymphoedema may be defined as abnormal limb swelling caused by the accumulation of increased amounts of high protein ISF secondary to defective lymphatic drainage in the presence of (near) normal net capillary filtration Aetiological classification of lymphoedema: Primary lymphoedema Congenital (onset <2 years old): sporadic; familial (Nonne–Milroy’s disease) Praecox (onset 2–35 years old): sporadic; familial (Letessier–Meige’s disease) Tarda (onset after 35 years old) Secondary lymphoedema A parasitic infection (filariasis) Fungal infection (tinea pedis) Exposure to foreign body material (silica particles) Primary malignancy Metastatic spread to lymph nodes Radiotherapy to lymph nodes Surgical excision of lymph nodes Trauma (particularly degloving injuries) Superficial thrombophlebitis Deep venous thrombosis. Diagnosis : Unlike other types of edema, lymphoedema characteristically involves the foot. The contour of the ankle is lost through infilling of the Sub malleolar depressions A ‘buffalo hump’ forms on the dorsum of the foot, The toes appear ‘square’ because of the confinement of footwear and The skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis (Stemmer’s sign) . Lymphoedema usually spreads proximally to knee level & less commonly affects the whole leg. Chronic eczema, fungal infection of the skin (dermatophytosis) and nails (onychomycosis), fissuring, verrucae, and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced disease. Ulceration is unusual, except in the presence of chronic venous insufficiency

questions.text: With regards to the removal of a chest drain: Assertion(A): During the removal of a chest drain, the patient should be asked to breathe in and hold their breath. Reason(R): No air is sucked into the pleural cavity as the tube is removed

options.label: A
options.text: Both, A and R, are true and R is the correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: Both, A and R, are true but R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: If A is true but R is false

options.label: D
options.text: If A is false but R is true

questions.correct_answer: A. Both, A and R, are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both, A and R, are true and R is the correct explanation of A During the removal of a chest drain the patient is asked to hold their breath to prevent the incidence of pneumothorax.

Highyeild:

Removal of Drains : Drains placed to signal perioperative bleeding may usually be removed after 24 hours. Drains put in because of infection should be left until the infection is subsiding or the drainage is minimal. Drains placed following routine bowel anastomoses should be removed at 3–5 days. A suction drain should have the suction taken off before removal of the drain . During the removal of a chest drain, the patient should be asked to breathe in and hold their breath, thus doing a Valsalva maneuver . In this way, no air is sucked into the pleural cavity as the tube is removed.

Extraedge:

Barbed sutures are increasingly being used for fascial closure. This suture has tiny barbs in a helical arrangement that allow an even distribution of tension across the incision rather than just at the knots Barbed sutures have also been shown to have a similar hernia recurrence rate in fascial plication for rectus diastasis . They are secured without knots, thus allowing for faster placement, and eliminate the knot as a nidus for infection.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not an indication of the placement of nasogastric tubes?

options.label: A
options.text: Conservative management of postoperative paralytic ileus

options.label: B
options.text: Suspected or proven base of skull fracture

options.label: C
options.text: Decompression of the stomach before an emergency operation

options.label: D
options.text: In the patient with motor neuron disease or stroke

questions.correct_answer: B. Suspected or proven base of skull fracture
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Suspected or proven base of skull fracture Suspected or proven base of skull fracture as this may result in inadvertent cranial injury Indications for placement of the nasogastric tube Drainage purposes : Conservative management of postoperative paralytic ileus Conservative management of bowel obstruction (adhesional or partial) Decompression of the stomach before an emergency operation Prophylactically, when postoperative ileus is anticipated following extensive bowel handling Feeding purposes : Following procedures in the upper aerodigestive tract (nasogastric or nasoenteral) In the patient with motor neuron disease or stroke Contraindications : Suspected or proven base of skull fracture as this may result in inadvertent cranial injury Esophageal stricture or recent esophageal surgery (unless under vision)
